conclusion: Determine the radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface where light rays are transmitted using Snell's Law and geometry.
The hemispherical shell has an inner radius R and an outer radius √2R. A parallel beam of light with a cross-sectional radius R is incident on the inner surface, parallel to the axis of symmetry.
Snell's Law: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2, where n1 and n2 are refractive indices, and θ1 and θ2 are angles of incidence and refraction.
Since the light is incident normally, θ1 = 0°, so sin θ1 = 0, leading to sin θ2 = 0 and θ2 = 0°.
The light ray travels along the axis of symmetry, passing through the center of the hemispherical shell.
The light ray emerges from the outer surface at the point directly opposite to the point of incidence. The distance from the center to the outer surface is √2R - R = R.
The radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface is the radius of the outer surface, √2R.
The radius of the circular boundary where light rays are transmitted is √2R.
